Measures are recorded as ‘identified’ where at least one substantive energy efficiency measure was documented in the dataset.

fn.p: Analysis by Built to Perform (2018) found average energy efficiency of pre-2000 housing stock was below 2 stars NatHERS equivalent. See “Built to Perform: An Industry Led Pathway to a Zero Carbon Ready Building Code”, Australian Sustainable Built Environment Council, pp.24-26. Website: www.asbec.asn.au/research

The 2003 Building Code of Australia introduced mandatory minimum energy efficiency requirements through Part 3.12 (Class 1 and 10 buildings). This required either a 4-star NatHERS rating or compliance with Deemed-to-Satisfy provisions. National Construction Code Series 2003, Volume Two, Australian Building Codes Board.

International Energy Agency review (2020) found Australia’s residential building energy standards were “significantly less stringent than those in other major economies.” See “Energy Policies of IEA Countries: Australia 2020 Review”, pp.89-91.

National Energy Productivity Plan 2015-2030, Council of Australian Governments Energy Council, December 2015. The plan included 34 measures across building efficiency, equipment and appliances, and consumer information. Website: www.energy.gov.au/government-priorities/energy-productivity-and-energy-efficiency/national-energy-productivity-plan

NatHERS was developed by CSIRO and has become the primary tool for rating residential energy efficiency, covering over 90% of new homes. Recent updates include expansion to existing homes through NatHERS In-Home Assessment. See www.nathers.gov.au/about

The National Dialogue on Universal Housing Design (2010-2014) set voluntary targets for accessible housing features by 2020. Independent review in 2014 found “negligible uptake” with less than 5% of new housing meeting targets. Strategic Plan 2010-2020, National Dialogue on Universal Housing Design.

NCC 2022 Volume Two requires new Class 1 buildings to achieve minimum 7-star NatHERS rating plus whole-of-home energy use requirements. Expected to reduce energy bills by $183-$935 annually per household. National Construction Code 2022, Volume Two, Section H6E4.

Implementation varies significantly: ACT and NSW adopted 7-star requirement in 2022; Victoria and Queensland in May 2024; WA planned for 2025; Tasmania declined adoption; NT implementing 5-star only. Status from state building authorities as of January 2025.

Review by COAG Energy Council (2019) identified “significant implementation and compliance challenges” from fragmented responsibilities. Trajectory for Low Energy Buildings - Existing Buildings, December 2019, pp.45-48.

Australian Bureau of Statistics data shows 86% of housing stock was built before 2003 introduction of energy efficiency requirements. Around 97% built before current 7-star standard. Housing Occupancy and Costs 2019-20, ABS.

International comparison by Climate Council (2022) found Australia “lagging major economies in residential energy efficiency improvement rate” - averaging 0.3% annual improvement vs 1.5-2% in comparable countries. “Home Energy Efficiency Report”, Climate Council Australia.

The NCC’s energy efficiency provisions have evolved from basic thermal requirements in 2003 to comprehensive performance standards in 2022. Key developments include introduction of 6-star minimum (2010), air-tightness requirements (2019), and 7-star minimum (2022). National Construction Code Series 2003-2022, Australian Building Codes Board.

Analysis of state implementation reveals significant variation: ACT achieved average 7.3 stars for new homes by 2023, while Tasmania maintained 6-star minimum. Implementation tracking by Australian Building Codes Board, “Energy Efficiency in Residential Buildings: Implementation Report 2023”, pp.12-15.

The Household Energy Upgrades Fund (2023-2027) provides loans for: heat pump installations ($5,000-15,000), solar PV systems ($5,000-20,000), and comprehensive retrofits ($15,000-50,000). Clean Energy Finance Corporation, “Program Guidelines 2023”, www.cefc.com.au/household-energy-upgrades

Social housing component prioritizes properties with poor energy performance (below 3 stars NatHERS equivalent) and high energy cost burden (>10% of household income). Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water, “Social Housing Energy Performance Program Guidelines”, December 2023.

Your Home guide (www.yourhome.gov.au) receives over 500,000 annual visits and covers 150+ topics. Energy.gov.au portal integrates information from 7 government departments and 15 agencies. Usage statistics from Digital Transformation Agency, 2023.
NatHERS coverage has expanded from 80% of new homes in 2015 to 95% in 2023. However, only 2% of existing homes have received ratings. NatHERS Administrator, “Annual Report 2022-23”, pp.8-10.
The Trajectory’s Existing Buildings Addendum (2019) set 26 priority actions for 2020-2023. By 2024, only 15 were completed. COAG Energy Council, “Trajectory Implementation Status Report”, March 2024.

Constitutional responsibility for housing rests with states/territories under s.51 powers. Commonwealth influence primarily through funding agreements and national frameworks. Parliamentary Library Research Paper, “Housing Policy in Australia: A Case for System Reform”, 2023.
Review of policy effectiveness shows voluntary schemes achieving 15-30% uptake vs. 80%+ for mandatory programs. Productivity Commission, “Energy Efficiency Programs Review”, 2024.

9.8 million of Australia’s 10.8 million homes were built before current energy standards. Approximately 95% would not meet 7-star requirements. Australian Bureau of Statistics, “Housing Data Series 2023”.

Analysis of state implementation approaches reveals policy innovation primarily driven by state governments, with 85% of new energy efficiency initiatives originating at state level between 2020-2024. Energy Efficiency Council, “State of Energy Efficiency 2024”, pp.15-18.

Detailed tracking of NCC 2022 implementation shows correlation between adoption timing and existing state energy efficiency frameworks. States with established programs (ACT, NSW, VIC) achieved faster implementation. Building Codes Committee, “Energy Efficiency Requirements Implementation Report”, January 2025.

Victorian Energy Upgrades delivered over 6.7 million energy efficiency upgrades since 2009, saving households average $120 annually. Program expanded in 2023 to include electrification activities. Essential Services Commission Victoria, “VEU Performance Report 2023”.

NSW Energy Security Safeguard combines Energy Savings Scheme with Peak Demand Reduction Scheme, targeting 13 million tonnes CO2-e reduction by 2030. Queensland Energy Savers achieved 24,000 upgrades in 2023-24. State program annual reports.

SHEPI program targets properties with highest energy cost burden, expecting 30-40% energy bill reduction. Early results show average savings of $580 annually per household. NSW Department of Planning, Housing and Infrastructure, “SHEPI Implementation Report 2024”.

Solar for Rentals program analysis shows 80% uptake in targeted areas, with average tenant savings of $745 annually. Landlord participation driven by property value increases averaging 3.8%. Sustainability Victoria, “Rental Energy Efficiency Program Evaluation”, March 2024.

Energy Ahead provided 15,000 home assessments in 2023-24, with 85% of participants implementing recommended measures. Average household savings of $420 annually. Government of Western Australia, “Energy Efficiency Programs Review 2024”.

SA Virtual Power Plant network grew to 25,000 connected households by 2024, providing 85MW dispatchable capacity while reducing participant bills by average 22%. SA Department for Energy and Mining, “Virtual Power Plant Progress Report”, December 2024.

Battery Boost Grant program facilitated 12,000 residential battery installations in 2023-24, integrating with broader grid modernization initiatives. Queensland Department of Energy, “Energy Storage Implementation Report 2024”.

Victorian Gas Substitution Roadmap coordinates efficiency improvements with electrification, targeting 250,000 household gas-to-electric conversions by 2025. Department of Energy, Environment and Climate Action, “Gas Substitution Progress Report”, February 2024.

Smart Green Apartments achieved average 34% reduction in energy consumption across 172 participating buildings (2020-2024). Program evaluation shows $3.12 million cumulative cost savings. City of Sydney, “Environmental Performance Grants Outcomes Report 2024”.

Zero Net Carbon Homes program facilitated 450 high-performance home constructions, averaging 8.2 stars NatHERS. Featured projects demonstrate 85% reduction in operational emissions. City of Melbourne, “Climate Action Plan Progress Report”, January 2025.

Zero Carbon Moreland engaged 7,500 households through 120 trained community advisors, achieving 22% average reduction in household emissions. Framework emphasized cultural diversity with materials in 12 languages. Moreland City Council, “Climate Action Implementation Report 2024”.

Sustainability Incentives Scheme distributed $4.8 million in rebates (2022-2024), leveraging $28.5 million private investment. Tiered structure achieved average improvement of 2.8 NatHERS stars. City of Adelaide, “Sustainability Incentives Review”, December 2024.

Brisbane’s guide influenced 65% of new home designs in target areas, with 85% of users reporting improved understanding of energy efficiency principles. Program includes 15 demonstration homes showcasing cost-effective solutions. Brisbane City Council, “Sustainable Housing Outcomes Report 2024”.

Better Business Partnership engaged 180 local contractors in energy efficiency upgrades, creating standardized assessment tools and quality assurance frameworks. Program facilitated 2,800 household improvements. Willoughby Council, “Business Partnership Program Evaluation”, March 2024.

Solar My Rental achieved 45% uptake in target areas through innovative split-incentive model. Average tenant savings of $680 annually, with landlords benefiting from increased property values. Inner West Council, “Rental Solar Program Review”, February 2024.

Building Futures program completed detailed assessments of 85 apartment buildings, identifying $12.5 million potential efficiency improvements. Implementation support achieved 65% conversion rate. Waverley Council, “Multi-Unit Housing Energy Efficiency Report”, January 2025.

Bendigo’s policy required 7.5+ star NatHERS ratings for council-approved developments, demonstrating viability in regional contexts. Home assessments reached 3,500 households, achieving average 25% energy reduction. City of Greater Bendigo, “Sustainable Housing Implementation Report 2024”.

Byron’s strategy leveraged 12 community partnerships to deliver energy efficiency services, reaching 28% of households despite limited council resources. Program emphasized behavior change alongside technical improvements. Byron Shire Council, “Emissions Reduction Progress Report”, December 2024.

Clean Energy Council accreditation covers 84% of solar installers nationwide, with approved products list referenced in 92% of government programs. Standards development involves 150+ industry stakeholders. CEC, “Industry Standards Report 2024”, pp.12-15.

GBCA voluntary standards achieved 45% market penetration in new multi-residential developments by 2024. Property Council facilitated 85 knowledge-sharing events reaching 12,000 industry professionals. Industry association annual reports 2024.

Community housing providers delivered energy efficiency upgrades to 85,000 properties (2020-2024), achieving average energy cost reductions of 32% while maintaining affordable rents. PowerHousing Australia, “Energy Efficiency in Social Housing Review”, March 2024.

CHIA’s initiative developed tenant-focused energy efficiency guidelines in 8 languages, training 250 housing workers. Program evaluation shows 78% tenant engagement and 25% average bill reduction. CHIA, “Sustainable Housing Progress Report”, February 2024.

ACOSS research identified potential annual savings of $1,200 per low-income household through improved energy efficiency. Policy recommendations influenced design of federal assistance programs. ACOSS, “Energy Affordability Review 2024”.

One Million Homes Alliance expanded to 45 member organizations, developing detailed implementation pathways for residential energy efficiency improvements. Coalition achieved significant policy influence in Victoria. Environment Victoria, “Alliance Impact Report”, January 2024.

National Dialogue’s voluntary approach achieved only 5% of targeted accessible housing features by 2014, leading to subsequent adoption of mandatory standards in most jurisdictions. Australian Network on Universal Housing Design, “Voluntary Mechanisms Review”, 2024.

Analysis identifies four key opportunity areas for non-government actors, with potential to deliver 45% of required residential energy efficiency improvements by 2030. Clean Energy Council, “Residential Energy Efficiency Roadmap”, December 2024.

Review of 250+ energy efficiency initiatives found only 15% had comprehensive evaluation frameworks. Gap particularly acute for non-government programs. Energy Efficiency Council, “Program Evaluation Synthesis”, March 2024.

Analysis of 12 OECD countries by International Energy Agency shows countries with mandatory disclosure achieving average 2.2% annual efficiency improvement vs Australia’s 0.3%. IEA, “Energy Efficiency Policy Review”, 2024.

Victorian mandatory disclosure pilot program (2023-24) demonstrated 15% price premium for high-performing properties and accelerated uptake of efficiency improvements. Results from initial 2,500 property transactions.
Compliance audit of 2,500 developments across five jurisdictions found 35% variation in achieved energy efficiency standards. ABCB, “Energy Efficiency Compliance Study”, February 2024.
Analysis shows only 5% of energy efficiency programs have comprehensive outcome data. National framework could reduce evaluation costs by 60%. CSIRO, “Energy Efficiency Data Infrastructure Review”.
Over 30% of Australian homes have solar installed - world’s highest per-capita penetration. Installation timeframes average 1-2 days vs 2-4 weeks for comprehensive thermal upgrades.
Modeling by Renew (2024) shows combined solar+battery+electrification savings of $2,200 annually for average household, with 4-6 year payback period.
Rental properties average 2.3 stars lower NatHERS rating than owner-occupied homes. Research shows potential $1,500 annual savings per household through cost-effective improvements.
Review of 45 major energy efficiency programs found upfront costs cited as primary barrier by 82% of eligible non-participants. Energy Efficiency Council, “Program Analysis”, 2024.
US PACE programs show 85% higher uptake vs traditional financing. Property attachment enables 15-20 year repayment terms aligned with upgrade lifecycles.
Industry capacity modeling indicates current workforce can deliver approximately 75,000 comprehensive retrofits annually - far below required pace for 2030 targets.

Analysis of 2,500 ‘whole house’ retrofits found average completion time of 12 weeks and mean cost of $42,000. Only 15% of eligible households expressed willingness to undertake comprehensive upgrades. Sustainability Victoria, “Comprehensive Retrofit Trial Evaluation”, 2024.

Industry capacity assessment indicates current thermal retrofit completion rate of 25,000 homes annually would need to increase 8-fold to meet 2030 targets. Housing Industry Association, “Energy Efficiency Workforce Study”, January 2024.

Over 3.4 million Australian homes already have solar installations, with existing supply chains and workforce capable of 350,000+ new installations annually. Clean Energy Council, “Clean Energy Australia Report”, 2024.
Installation timeframes from 500 monitored projects show median 1.8 days for solar-battery vs 16.5 days for comprehensive thermal upgrades. CSIRO, “Retrofit Delivery Analysis”, March 2024.

Construction workforce analysis shows 12,500 qualified thermal retrofit installers nationally, with 6-month training requirement for new entrants. Current annual training capacity of 2,800. TAFE Directors Australia, “Energy Efficiency Skills Report”, 2024.

Supply chain modeling indicates 240% increase in insulation material demand would be required for large-scale thermal retrofit program, exceeding current domestic production capacity by 180%. Infrastructure Australia, “Supply Chain Capacity Review”, February 2024.

Early results from BOOM! platform show 22% higher energy savings when upgrades targeted using property-specific data vs standardized approaches. Analysis of 15,000 properties across 5 jurisdictions. Energy Efficiency Council, “Digital Platforms Review”, 2024.

Irish experience shows 85% higher uptake of energy efficiency measures following transition from voluntary to mandatory disclosure. Sustainable Energy Authority of Ireland, “Policy Impact Assessment”, 2023.
Framework development by CSIRO identifies 5 critical success factors from analysis of 12 international retrofit programs. “Retrofit Quality Framework”, 2024.

Analysis of 25 Australian subsidy programs shows average uptake of 12% among eligible households, with upfront costs cited as primary barrier by 82% of non-participants. Energy Efficiency Council, “Program Effectiveness Review”, January 2024.

US PACE programs show 85% higher uptake vs traditional financing. Average project size $21,000 with 15-20 year terms. $9.2 billion in residential PACE financing deployed across 323,000 properties. PACENation Market Data, 2024.

Utility-based financing programs achieve 65% higher participation rates compared to traditional loans. Review of 8 major US programs shows average default rates below 1%. American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy, “Utility Finance Models”, 2024.

NRN model demonstrates successful integration of financing with VPP participation, achieving 22% reduction in household energy costs. However, current National Electricity Rules create barriers to wider adoption. Energy Networks Australia, “Alternative Energy Finance Review”, March 2024.

CEFC modeling indicates $1 billion program could leverage $3.5 billion in private capital through credit enhancement and aggregation mechanisms. Program design based on successful international green banks. CEFC, “Household Energy Program Design”, 2024.

Review of financing programs finds 45% higher energy savings when combined with standardized technical requirements and contractor certification. International Energy Agency, “Finance Program Best Practices”, 2024.

Income analysis of financing program participants shows bottom income quartile represents only 8% of participants despite comprising 35% of eligible properties. Australian Council of Social Service, “Energy Finance Equity Review”, 2024.

SA Switch for Solar achieved 65% uptake among eligible concession holders, demonstrating viability of rebate redirection model. Average participant savings of $725 annually. South Australian Government Program Evaluation, December 2023.

Framework analysis identifies 5 critical success factors from review of 15 international financing programs. Most successful programs incorporated all elements. CSIRO, “Energy Efficiency Finance Report”, February 2024.

Analysis of 35 energy efficiency programs finds behavioral factors explain 45% of variation in uptake rates, compared to 30% for financial factors. Energy Consumers Australia, “Behavioral Insights Study”, January 2024.

Survey data shows 35% of households cite trust concerns about energy efficiency programs, with highest concerns among demographics most exposed to previous program failures. Essential Research, “Energy Program Trust Survey”, 2024.

Moreland program achieved 85% higher uptake rates in areas with active community energy advisors vs control areas. Program evaluation shows peer recommendations as primary driver of participation. Moreland City Council, “Zero Carbon Framework Evaluation”, March 2024.

Meta-analysis of efficiency programs shows average 20-30% rebound effect, with higher rates for low-income households previously experiencing deprivation. Energy Policy Research Institute, “Rebound Effect Analysis”, 2024.

Community-based programs achieve average 65% higher participation rates and 40% greater energy savings vs traditional marketing approaches. Review of 25 programs across 8 jurisdictions. Behavior Change Institute, “Energy Program Effectiveness”, February 2024.

ACT scheme achieved 45% participation rate among eligible households, with community education sessions increasing uptake by 85% among attendees. ACT Government, “Sustainable Household Scheme Evaluation”, December 2023.

Household surveys show average 40% underestimation of potential energy savings from efficiency improvements. Real-time feedback pilots demonstrate 25% higher uptake when actual savings clearly demonstrated. Energy Efficiency Council, “Information Barriers Study”, 2024.

Framework analysis identifies 6 critical success factors for community engagement from review of international programs. Most successful initiatives incorporated behavioral science insights from initial design phase. CSIRO, “Community Energy Program Design”, January 2024.

Modeling indicates coordinated planning could reduce total system costs by $12-15 billion through 2030 compared to uncoordinated approach. Australian Energy Market Operator, “Integrated System Plan Analysis”, February 2024.

SA VPP program demonstrates 85% reduction in local network constraints and average 22% bill reduction for participating households. Analysis of 25,000 connected systems. SA Power Networks, “VPP Performance Review”, 2024.

Network investment analysis shows potential $4.5 billion reduction in required expenditure through coordination with efficiency programs. Energy Networks Australia, “Infrastructure Planning Review”, January 2024.

Community battery pilots achieve 40% higher utilization rates vs individual systems, reducing per-household costs by 35%. Results from 15 pilot sites across 5 jurisdictions. ARENA, “Community Battery Assessment”, March 2024.
Tariff analysis identifies $250-400 annual undervaluation of household contributions to network efficiency under current structures. AEMC, “Network Pricing Review”, 2024.

System integration framework identifies 5 key requirements based on review of international programs. Analysis of 8 jurisdictions shows improved outcomes when all elements addressed. CSIRO, “Energy System Integration”, February 2024.

sec.title: Notes: SA
sec.p: South Australia has declared a Climate Emergency and is committed to achieving net-zero emissions by 20501. In line with this ambition, the state government is actively promoting energy efficiency in residential housing through a range of policies, regulations, schemes, and other measures. This report provides a comprehensive overview of these efforts, drawing on a variety of sources, including government websites, academic research papers, reports from NGOs, news articles, and websites of energy providers.
Several government agencies and departments play a crucial role in developing and implementing energy efficiency initiatives in South Australia. These include:

tr.td: Develops and implements energy efficiency policies and programs.
Promotes sustainable living, including energy efficiency, and protects the environment.
Essential Services Commission of South Australia (ESCOSA)
Sets energy prices, promotes competition in the energy market, and has a role in promoting energy efficiency.
Department of the Premier and Cabinet
Has overarching responsibility for government policy, including energy efficiency.
Provides shared services to government agencies and promotes energy efficiency within government operations.
Administers the Building Code of Australia in South Australia.
Department of Industry, Science, Energy and Resources (DISER)
Provides grants for community energy efficiency and solar projects through the Energy Efficient Communities Program.

sec.p: The Building Code of Australia (BCA) is a national code adopted by each state and territory, setting minimum energy efficiency standards for new residential buildings. In South Australia, the BCA is administered by the Department for Infrastructure and Transport9. The BCA’s energy efficiency provisions aim to reduce energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions from residential buildings by setting requirements for:

list-item.p: Building envelope: This includes requirements for insulation, glazing, and air tightness to minimize heat loss and gain.
Heating and cooling systems: This includes minimum energy efficiency standards for heating and cooling systems, such as air conditioners and heat pumps.
Hot water systems: This includes requirements for the energy efficiency of hot water systems, such as solar hot water systems and heat pumps.
Lighting: This includes requirements for energy-efficient lighting, such as LED lights.

sec.p: The South Australian government offers various schemes and incentives to encourage energy efficiency in residential housing:

list-item.p: Retailer Energy Productivity Scheme (REPS): This scheme requires energy retailers to meet energy savings targets by providing energy efficiency products and services to households10. Retailers can achieve these targets by offering discounts on energy-efficient appliances, providing energy audits, and installing energy-saving devices. To meet their targets, retailers can use energy credits earned in previous years, although the use of credits is being phased out11.

Home Energy Efficiency Scheme: This scheme provides financial assistance to homeowners to install energy-efficient products and appliances12. Eligible upgrades may include insulation, solar hot water systems, and energy-efficient lighting. The scheme aims to reduce household energy consumption and lower energy bills.

Community Batteries for Household Solar: This program, funded by the Australian Renewable Energy Agency (ARENA), supports the installation of community batteries in South Australia13. These batteries allow households with solar panels to store excess energy and use it during peak demand periods, reducing reliance on the grid and maximizing the benefits of solar power. The program also provides eligible SA Housing Trust tenants with access to an exclusive energy plan with a reduced tariff14.

sec.p: In addition to government schemes, homeowners can implement various measures to improve the energy efficiency of their homes:

list-item.p: Installing insulation: Insulation helps to reduce heat loss in winter and heat gain in summer, leading to lower energy consumption for heating and cooling15. Different types of insulation are available for ceilings, walls, and floors.

Using energy-efficient appliances: Energy-efficient appliances, such as refrigerators, washing machines, and dishwashers, consume less energy than standard appliances16. Look for appliances with high energy star ratings to maximize energy savings.

title.bold: Role of the Essential Services Commission of South Australia

sec.p: The Essential Services Commission of South Australia (ESCOSA) plays a vital role in promoting energy efficiency through various mechanisms:

list-item.p: Setting energy prices: ESCOSA sets energy prices to ensure they are fair and reasonable, which can incentivize energy efficiency by making it more expensive to use excessive energy17. By reflecting the true cost of energy, ESCOSA’s pricing structures encourage consumers to reduce their energy consumption.

Promoting competition in the energy market: Competition in the energy market can lead to lower prices and more innovative energy efficiency products and services18. ESCOSA fosters competition by ensuring a level playing field for energy retailers and encouraging new entrants into the market.

sec.p: Energy providers in South Australia also contribute to promoting energy efficiency. While specific programs and rebates vary between providers, some common offerings include:

list-item.p: Discounts on energy-efficient appliances: Some providers offer discounts on energy-efficient appliances, such as refrigerators and washing machines, to encourage customers to upgrade to more energy-saving models19.
Energy audits: Some providers offer free or subsidized energy audits to help customers identify areas where they can improve energy efficiency in their homes20.
Installation of energy-saving devices: Some providers offer free or subsidized installation of energy-saving devices, such as smart thermostats and energy-efficient lighting21.
Bundled discounts: Dodo offers a monthly discount to customers who bundle their electricity and nbn plans22.

sec.p: Several NGOs and other organizations are actively involved in promoting energy efficiency in South Australia:

list-item.p: The Energy Efficiency Council (EEC): The EEC is a not-for-profit membership association that promotes energy efficiency across the Australian economy23. They advocate for policies that support energy efficiency, provide information and resources to businesses and consumers, and promote best practices in energy management.

CORENA South Australia: CORENA is a not-for-profit organization that supports community-based renewable energy projects24. They provide funding and support for projects that promote the uptake of renewable energy and energy efficiency in communities.

Tutti Arts South Australia: Tutti Arts is a multi-arts organization that supports artists with disabilities25. They have a program that provides energy-efficient lighting to artists, helping them reduce their energy consumption and costs.

sec.p: Academic research provides valuable insights into the factors that influence energy consumption in homes and the effectiveness of different energy efficiency measures. Some key findings from research on energy efficiency in residential housing in South Australia include:

list-item.p: Gap between expected and actual benefits: Research has shown that there can be a gap between the expected and actual benefits of energy-efficient housing26. This highlights the importance of considering occupant behavior and providing ongoing support to ensure that energy-efficient features are used effectively.

Incentives and barriers to adoption: Financial incentives, such as rebates and grants, can play a significant role in encouraging the adoption of energy-efficient measures27. However, barriers such as upfront costs and lack of awareness can hinder the uptake of energy efficiency.

Role of occupants: Occupant behavior plays a crucial role in achieving energy savings in residential buildings28. Educating occupants about energy-efficient practices and providing feedback on their energy consumption can help to maximize the benefits of energy-efficient features.

sec.p: The South Australian government is investing in energy efficiency upgrades for social housing properties29. This initiative aims to improve the comfort and affordability of social housing for tenants while reducing energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions. Upgrades may include insulation, energy-efficient appliances, and solar panels.

Recognizing the impact of rising energy costs on small businesses, the South Australian government has increased its support for energy efficiency in the business sector30. Due to unprecedented demand for the Energy Efficiency Grants scheme, the government lifted the cap on Round 2 of the program, allowing more businesses to access grants for energy-efficient equipment and upgrades31. This demonstrates the government’s commitment to supporting businesses in reducing their energy costs and improving their sustainability.

South Australia is exploring new policy mechanisms to ensure grid stability and reliability as it transitions to a 100% renewable energy grid by 202732. One such mechanism is the proposed “Firm Energy Reliability Mechanism,” which would provide payments to long-duration energy storage, including batteries and potentially gas generators33. This mechanism aims to address the challenges of “dunkelflaute,” a term describing periods of low wind and solar generation34.

Ensuring equitable access to energy efficiency measures is crucial for achieving a just energy transition. While South Australia has made significant progress in promoting energy efficiency, challenges remain in ensuring that all households, including those in remote communities, can benefit from these initiatives35. Targeted programs and support are needed to address the specific needs of remote and disadvantaged communities, ensuring that they can access the benefits of energy efficiency and contribute to a sustainable energy future.

South Australia has a strong commitment to energy efficiency in residential housing, driven by its ambitious climate targets and a desire to reduce energy costs for households and businesses. The government has implemented a comprehensive suite of policies, regulations, schemes, and incentives to promote energy efficiency, complemented by the efforts of energy providers, NGOs, and academic researchers. While significant progress has been made, challenges remain in ensuring equitable access to energy efficiency measures and maintaining grid stability as the state transitions to a renewable energy future.

title.bold: Energy Efficiency in New Residential Buildings

sec.p: Victoria has implemented stringent energy efficiency requirements for new homes to reduce energy consumption, greenhouse gas emissions, and improve occupant comfort1. The state aims to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050 and has set ambitious targets to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 45-50% from 2005 levels by 20302. Given that residential buildings are a significant contributor to Australia’s overall emissions, they represent a key area for improvement3.

In 2022, Victoria raised the minimum energy efficiency building standards for new homes from 6 to 7 stars4. This change necessitates improvements in insulation, window glazing, and the use of energy-efficient appliances in new homes5. The 7-star standard ensures that new homes are designed and built to minimize energy consumption and maximize thermal comfort. Notably, this shift towards higher energy efficiency standards has created a demand for new skills and occupations in the building sector, with professionals now required to design and implement these energy-efficient measures6.

To support the transition to 7-star homes, Sustainability Victoria’s 7 Star Homes program provided rebates and verification assessments to builders and land developers7. This program aimed to accelerate the adoption of energy-efficient practices in the residential building market. For instance, the program offered $4,000 rebates per home, for up to 4 homes built, to assist with upgrade costs and provided as-built verification assessments to ensure homes are built to achieve the same efficiency rating as designed8.

The NCC establishes the energy efficiency requirements for new homes, renovations, alterations, and additions9. The NCC aims to enhance the sustainability and liveability of buildings by reducing energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions while improving occupant health and amenity10.

Performance requirement H6P1 in the NCC mandates that habitable rooms and conditioned spaces use less energy than the calculated heating and cooling loads11. This requirement promotes the construction of building fabrics that minimize reliance on artificial heating and cooling, thereby reducing energy consumption.

title.bold: Energy Efficiency in Existing Residential Buildings

sec.p: Recognizing that existing homes constitute a substantial portion of the housing stock, Victoria has implemented various programs and initiatives to improve their energy efficiency.

The One Million Homes Alliance, a collaborative effort between leading environment, social sector, local government, and consumer organizations, is committed to transforming the efficiency and affordability of Victoria’s housing12. This alliance advocates for policies and programs that promote energy efficiency upgrades in existing homes.

The VEU program is a key initiative aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions by providing Victorians with access to discounted energy-efficient products and services13. The program encourages investment, employment, and innovation in industries that supply these products and services14.

Under the VEU program, large energy retailers are required to acquire and surrender Victorian energy efficiency certificates (VEECs) to meet annual targets set by legislation15. Accredited persons who install energy-efficient products in homes can create VEECs16.
The VEU program offers various incentives for homeowners to improve their energy efficiency, including discounts on a range of upgrades. These are summarized in the table below:

tr.td: Electric heat pump hot water system

sec.p: In addition to these upgrades, VEU also offers home energy rating assessments to provide targeted recommendations for improving energy efficiency17.

The VEU program has been successful in driving the adoption of energy-efficient technologies. Since the introduction of new electrification activities in mid-2023, over 24,000 Victorians have switched to efficient electric heating and cooling, and over 34,000 have upgraded to heat pump water heaters18. Importantly, 90% of VEU participants are satisfied with the program and the installed products, highlighting its positive impact on consumers19.

title.bold: Energy Efficiency in Social Housing Program (EESHP)

sec.p: The EESHP is a joint initiative between the Victorian and Australian governments to improve the energy efficiency and liveability of social housing properties20. The program aims to deliver up to 45,000 individual energy efficiency upgrades, including 5,000 fully electrified homes21.

The EESHP specifically targets older social housing dwellings with gas appliances and low energy efficiency22. Renters in eligible properties are offered a package of upgrades to significantly improve their energy efficiency23.

Sustainability Victoria conducted a Comprehensive Retrofit Trial to assess the potential for energy efficiency upgrades in existing homes24. The trial involved a range of building shell, appliance, and lighting upgrades in 60 houses representative of Victoria’s housing stock25.

The trial demonstrated that significant energy and greenhouse gas savings could be achieved through comprehensive retrofits26. For example, the study found that comprehensive retrofits could reduce energy consumption by up to 70% and greenhouse gas emissions by up to 80%. The findings of this trial inform policy development and program design for improving energy efficiency in existing homes.

Victoria is actively pursuing the electrification of homes to reduce reliance on gas and transition to cleaner energy sources. This policy direction aligns with the Victorian government’s support for repowering homes with efficient electric appliances, a vital approach to lowering energy prices and reducing emissions27.

The Gas Substitution Roadmap outlines Victoria’s plan to phase out gas connections in new homes and transition to all-electric appliances28. This roadmap supports the state’s goal of achieving net-zero emissions by 2045.

title.bold: Regulatory Impact Statement on Building Electrification

sec.p: In 2024, the Victorian Government released a Regulatory Impact Statement on building electrification measures29. The preferred policy includes requiring gas appliances to be replaced with electric options at the end of their life and mandating all-electric systems in new homes and many new commercial buildings30.

These measures are expected to generate significant bill savings for Victorian households and contribute to the state’s emissions reduction targets31. For example, data from Renew indicates that ditching gas and switching to reverse cycle split systems for heating can save at least two-thirds of annual energy bills, with the upfront investment paying for itself within one year32.

title.bold: Energy Efficiency Regulations for Rental Properties

sec.p: The Victorian Government is committed to improving energy efficiency in rental properties to ensure affordable and comfortable living conditions for tenants. It is important to note that energy efficiency in rental properties is often lower than in owner-occupied homes, highlighting the need for specific regulations and support in this area33.

Rental homes in Victoria are required to have a fixed heater in the main living area with at least a 2-star energy rating34. In December 2023, the Gas Substitution Roadmap update proposed new energy efficiency standards for rental properties, including ceiling insulation, draught sealing, efficient hot water systems and showerheads, and cooling35.

Victoria has implemented a comprehensive suite of policies, regulations, and schemes to improve energy efficiency in residential housing. The state’s commitment to net-zero emissions by 204536 is driving the transition to energy-efficient building practices, the adoption of renewable energy technologies, and the electrification of homes.

The VEU program, EESHP, and proposed minimum energy efficiency standards for rental properties are key initiatives that are transforming the residential housing sector in Victoria. These measures are contributing to lower energy bills for households37, improved thermal comfort38, and reduced greenhouse gas emissions39.

title.bold: National Construction Code (NCC) 2022 Energy Efficiency Standards

sec.p: The NCC 2022 introduces new energy efficiency requirements for residential buildings across Australia, including Queensland. These standards aim to improve the energy performance of new homes and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Key aspects of the NCC 2022 include:

list-item.p: Whole-of-Home Rating: New houses and townhouses must achieve a minimum Whole-of-Home rating of 60 (out of 100), while new units must achieve a rating of 501.

Climate Zones: Queensland is divided into four climate zones, and the specific energy efficiency features required for compliance vary depending on the region. This ensures that the building design considers the local climate conditions to optimize energy performance2.
Expected Savings: The new standards are projected to deliver average annual electricity savings of $185 per household across Queensland3.

sec.p: The NCC 2022 provides detailed guidelines and specifications for various aspects of energy efficiency in residential buildings, including:

list-item.p: Building Fabric: Requirements for insulation, glazing, and thermal mass to minimize heat transfer. This includes specifications for insulation materials, R-values, and installation methods to ensure optimal thermal performance of walls, roofs, and floors.

Building Sealing: Standards for airtightness to reduce energy loss through drafts. This involves sealing gaps and cracks in the building envelope to prevent air leakage, improving energy efficiency and comfort.

Glazing: Specifications for window performance to control solar heat gain and minimize heat loss. This includes requirements for window U-values, solar heat gain coefficients (SHGC), and window frame materials to optimize energy performance.

Heating and Cooling: Requirements for energy-efficient heating and cooling systems. This includes minimum energy efficiency standards for heating and cooling equipment, such as air conditioners and heat pumps, as well as provisions for zoning and control systems to optimize energy use.

Hot Water Systems: Standards for energy-efficient hot water systems. This includes minimum energy efficiency ratings for hot water systems, such as solar hot water systems, heat pumps, and gas-fired systems, as well as requirements for insulation and pipe sizing to minimize heat loss.

Lighting: Requirements for energy-efficient lighting. This includes promoting the use of energy-efficient lighting technologies, such as LEDs, and specifying minimum energy efficiency standards for lighting fixtures.

sec.p: The Queensland Government has launched a new $22 million Climate Smart Energy Savers Program to help Queenslanders reduce their energy consumption and costs4. The program offers:

list-item.p: Rebates: Rebates of up to $1,000 for the purchase and installation of eligible energy-efficient appliances with a four-star energy rating5.
Eligible Appliances: Rebates are available for a range of appliances, including:

tr.td: Solar and heat pump hot water systems

sec.p: This program provides financial incentives for households to adopt energy-efficient appliances, contributing to lower energy bills and reduced emissions. The Climate Council research indicates that Queenslanders could save more than $800 per year by switching from gas hot water to a solar hot water system, making the program’s rebates a potentially compelling offer for many households6.

The Queensland Development Code (QDC) provides a comprehensive framework for planning and development in Queensland, ensuring sustainable and efficient building practices7. QDC Part 4.1 focuses on sustainable buildings and includes specific provisions for energy efficiency in residential housing. Key aspects of QDC Part 4.1 include:

list-item.p: Energy Efficiency Performance: Requirements for new residential buildings to meet minimum energy efficiency standards, aligned with the NCC.
Renewable Energy: Encouragement for the use of renewable energy sources, such as solar power, in residential buildings.
Water Efficiency: Provisions for water efficiency measures in residential buildings to conserve water resources.

sec.p: The Australian and Queensland Governments have partnered to deliver energy performance upgrades for social housing properties across the state. This $116 million initiative aims to improve thermal comfort, reduce energy consumption, and lower power bills for residents in social housing8. Key features of the initiative include:

list-item.p: Targeted Upgrades: Up to 32,000 social housing properties will receive energy performance upgrades, with an expected completion date of 20279.
Upgrade Measures: Upgrades may include ceiling insulation, air cooling solutions, ceiling fans, solar systems, and energy-efficient hot water systems10.
Improved Comfort: The upgrades will help to keep homes warmer in winter and cooler in summer, improving the quality of life for residents11.
Reduced Bills: The initiative is expected to reduce energy consumption and lower power bills for social housing residents12.
Funding: The initiative is jointly funded by the Queensland Government and the Australian Government13.
Broader Impacts: The initiative aims to support Queensland’s clean energy transformation and reduce the cost of living for vulnerable residents, highlighting its social and environmental benefits14.

sec.p: However, there are concerns that Queensland may miss out on federal funding for energy efficiency in social housing if the state government does not take more proactive steps to improve energy efficiency and promote rooftop solar in this sector15.

The Australian Government’s Energy Efficiency Grants for Small and Medium Sized Enterprises program provides grants to businesses to upgrade or replace inefficient equipment and implement energy efficiency activities16. While this program focuses on SMEs, it reflects the government’s commitment to energy efficiency and may indirectly benefit residential housing by driving innovation and adoption of energy-efficient technologies.

The MEEG Program is a Queensland Government initiative that provides grants ranging from $7,500 to $50,000 to manufacturers to improve energy efficiency measures and technology, reduce energy usage, costs, and emissions17. The program is part of the Queensland Energy and Jobs Plan and aligns with the Queensland Government’s Advanced Manufacturing 10-Year Roadmap and Action Plan18. The MEEG Program guidelines provide detailed information on eligibility criteria and funding amounts19.

The Australian Government, in collaboration with states and territories and the New Zealand Government, has implemented the Equipment Energy Efficiency (E3) Program to enhance the energy efficiency of appliances and equipment20. The program aims to deliver a single, integrated approach to energy efficiency standards and labeling. This involves setting minimum energy performance standards (MEPS) for appliances and equipment before they can be sold, and providing energy efficiency information through labels to help consumers make informed purchasing decisions21.

The E3 Program plays a crucial role in reducing energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions in the residential sector by promoting the use of energy-efficient appliances. By promoting the development and adoption of energy-efficient appliances and equipment, the program contributes to reducing greenhouse gas emissions and supports the transition to Net Zero22. Examples of appliances covered by the program include refrigerators, washing machines, and air conditioners. The energy rating labels provide consumers with information on the energy efficiency of these appliances, allowing them to make informed choices that can lead to lower energy bills and reduced environmental impact.
Several agencies and organizations in Queensland play a role in promoting energy efficiency in residential housing:

list-item.p: Anderson Energy Efficiency: A Queensland-based consultancy service that provides energy efficiency assessments for buildings23.
Energy and Water Ombudsman Queensland (EWOQ): Provides a dispute resolution service for energy consumers, including residential customers24.
Energy Efficiency Council (EEC): A national peak body for energy efficiency, with members in Queensland providing energy efficiency services25.
Energy Engineers: A Queensland-based company that offers energy audits and solar solutions to help businesses and households save energy26.

sec.p: The Queensland Energy DataBase is a valuable resource that provides time series data on Queensland’s energy production, consumption, and prices for all energy sources from 1970 to 201727. This database provides valuable insights into Queensland’s energy landscape, which can inform policy decisions and research on energy efficiency in residential housing.

Academic institutions in Queensland contribute to research on energy efficiency in residential housing. The University of Queensland, for example, has conducted research on energy efficiency and sustainability in buildings, with a focus on reducing energy consumption and carbon emissions on campus28.

Industry associations, such as the Master Builders Association of Queensland, provide resources and guidance on energy efficiency in residential construction, offering training programs, publications, and online resources to help builders and homeowners understand and implement energy-efficient building practices.

Queensland has implemented a range of policies, regulations, schemes, and initiatives to promote energy efficiency in residential housing. These measures aim to improve the energy performance of homes, reduce energy consumption, lower greenhouse gas emissions, and help households save money on their energy bills. The government’s commitment to energy efficiency is evident in programs like the NCC 2022, the Social Housing Energy Performance Initiative, and the Climate Smart Energy Savers Program.

While these initiatives demonstrate a strong commitment to energy efficiency, there are potential areas for improvement. Concerns have been raised about the potential for Queensland to miss out on federal funding for energy efficiency in social housing due to a perceived lack of urgency in addressing this issue29. This highlights the need for continued efforts to improve energy efficiency in social housing, including promoting the adoption of rooftop solar.

Furthermore, there is a need for greater awareness and education among homeowners about the benefits of energy efficiency and the available programs and incentives. Expanding outreach and education programs could encourage more homeowners to invest in energy-efficient upgrades and appliances.

Overall, Queensland’s energy efficiency policies for residential housing demonstrate a positive trend towards a more sustainable energy future. Continued efforts in this area, with a focus on addressing gaps and improving existing measures, will be crucial in achieving long-term energy efficiency goals and reducing the state’s carbon footprint.

sec.title: Notes: Cth
sec.p: This report draws on authoritative government publications and reports to provide a comprehensive overview of energy efficiency policies, regulations, schemes, and other measures relevant to residential housing in Australia at the Commonwealth (federal) level.

Australia has demonstrated a commitment to improving energy efficiency, setting a national target of 40% improvement in energy productivity by 20301. This target is linked to broader climate and energy security goals, as energy efficiency measures can contribute to a more resilient energy system2. While the country has made progress in energy savings since 2000 in the industrial and services sectors, primarily through efficiency disclosure regimes, labeling, and the Greenhouse and Energy Minimum Standards (GEMS) for appliances, improvement rates have slowed in recent years3. To achieve its ambitious target and contribute to net-zero emissions, Australia needs to accelerate its efforts and double annual improvement rates from their recent drag4.
The Australian Government is pursuing its energy and emissions reduction agenda through various initiatives, including:

list-item.p: The Energy and Climate Ministerial Council: This council facilitates collaboration between the Australian Government and state and territory governments on energy and climate policy5.

The National Energy Transformation Partnership: This partnership provides a framework for cooperation between different levels of government to transform Australia’s energy system and achieve net-zero emissions by 20506.

Powering Australia: This plan focuses on job creation, reducing energy bills, and lowering emissions by promoting renewable energy. It includes commitments to national climate leadership, energy sector transformation, industrial and agricultural decarbonization, and transport sector improvements7.

sec.p: The NCC sets minimum energy efficiency requirements for new homes to ensure they are sustainable, safe, and comfortable. In 2022, Building Ministers agreed to raise the minimum thermal energy rating for new homes, resulting in updated requirements in NCC 20228. These updates include:

list-item.p: Increased Star Ratings: New homes must now achieve the equivalent of 7 stars (out of 10) for NatHERS thermal performance9.

Whole of Home Rating: This new assessment predicts the annual energy use of a home, including heating, cooling, and on-site energy generation and storage. New houses must achieve a rating of 60 (out of 100), while new units must achieve 50 (out of 100)10.

sec.p: These changes are estimated to save an average of $183 per year on energy bills for new homes11. States and territories are adopting these requirements at various times.

title.bold: Greenhouse and Energy Minimum Standards (GEMS) Act

sec.p: The GEMS Act 2012 provides a national framework for appliance and equipment energy efficiency12. It promotes the development and adoption of energy-efficient appliances and equipment to reduce energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions. The GEMS Act includes:

list-item.p: Minimum Energy Performance Standards (MEPS): These standards specify the minimum level of energy performance that appliances and equipment must meet or exceed before they can be supplied or used for commercial purposes in Australia. MEPS are an effective way to increase the energy efficiency of products, ensuring they use less energy and have lower running costs over their lifetime13.
Energy Rating Label: This label allows consumers to compare the energy efficiency and running costs of appliances14.

sec.p: NatHERS is a critical component of Australia’s energy efficiency efforts in the residential sector. It provides a star rating (out of 10) based on the thermal performance of a home, indicating how much heating and cooling it will require15. Key aspects of NatHERS include:

list-item.p: NCC 2022 Integration: NatHERS is used to demonstrate compliance with the updated energy efficiency requirements in NCC 2022. New houses must achieve a minimum 7-star rating and a Whole of Home rating of 6016.
Assessment Tools: NatHERS-accredited software tools are used to assess the energy efficiency of homes based on their design, construction, and location17.

Expansion to Existing Homes: Expanding NatHERS to provide energy ratings for existing homes is a crucial step towards widespread energy efficiency improvements in the existing housing stock. These ratings will help homeowners understand their home’s energy performance and make informed decisions about upgrades, potentially unlocking access to “green loans” with lower interest rates18.

sec.p: While Australia does not have a national energy savings scheme, several schemes operate at the state and territory level, and the Commonwealth Government plays a role through national initiatives and funding programs19:

list-item.p: Household Energy Upgrades Fund: In the 2023-24 Budget, the Australian Government allocated $1.3 billion to establish this fund20. The Clean Energy Finance Corporation will manage $1 billion to partner with lenders and offer low-cost finance for energy performance upgrades in over 110,000 homes. Loans will be available to upgrade homes with battery-ready solar PV, modern energy-efficient appliances, and other improvements, creating more comfortable homes that waste less energy21.

Energy Savings Scheme (ESS) in New South Wales: This state-level scheme aims to deliver cost-effective energy savings for NSW households and businesses by providing financial incentives to install energy-efficient equipment and appliances22.

Investment in Energy-Saving Upgrades: In the 2023-24 Budget, the Australian Government invested $1.6 billion for energy-saving upgrades to social housing, homes, and businesses. This significant investment underscores the government’s commitment to improving energy efficiency across the residential sector23.

sec.title: Notes: ACT
sec.p: This report provides a comprehensive overview of energy efficiency policies, regulations, schemes, and other measures relevant to residential housing in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). The information presented here draws upon a variety of sources, including government websites1, PDF reports2, academic papers3, industry reports4, and news articles5.

The ACT Government is committed to improving energy efficiency in the residential sector to reduce energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions. This commitment is reflected in various policies and regulations, with key initiatives including:

list-item.p: Building Codes: The ACT has implemented building codes that mandate minimum energy performance standards for new residential buildings. These codes ensure that new homes are built with energy-efficient features, such as insulation, double glazing, and energy-efficient appliances. For example, new homes may be required to have a minimum level of insulation in walls and ceilings, and windows must meet certain energy efficiency standards6.

Energy Efficiency Certification: The ACT Government requires energy efficiency certification for residential buildings. This certification provides information about a building’s energy performance, using a standardized rating system, and helps buyers and renters make informed decisions7.

Appliance Standards and Labelling: The ACT has adopted energy efficiency standards and labelling for household appliances. This helps consumers identify and choose appliances that consume less energy by providing a clear and comparable energy efficiency rating on appliances8.

sec.p: The ACT Government is preparing to electrify the city and transition away from fossil fuel gas by 20459. This initiative aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and create a cleaner energy future for Canberra. The government plans to achieve this transition by phasing out gas connections in new suburbs and providing incentives for households to switch to electric appliances and heating systems. The benefits of an all-electric Canberra include reduced reliance on fossil fuels, improved air quality, and lower energy costs for households.
The ACT Government offers a range of schemes and programs to support households in improving the energy efficiency of their homes and to assist those facing housing stress:

list-item.p: Home Energy Efficiency Program: This free program provides advice and support to renters and homeowners on how to save money on energy bills while maintaining comfort. The program offers information kits with energy-saving tips, draught-proofing assistance, and in-home energy assessments to help households identify and implement energy-saving measures10.

Sustainable Household Scheme: This scheme provides interest-free loans to eligible households for energy-efficient upgrades, such as solar panels, battery storage, and efficient heating and cooling systems11.

Utilities Concession Scheme: This scheme offers discounts on electricity, natural gas, water, and sewerage bills to eligible households, including pensioners and low-income health care card holders12.

Supportive Tenancy Service: This service provides support to tenants who are in housing stress or at risk of homelessness. The service advocates for tenants with landlords and lenders, refers tenants to support services, and provides support at ACAT hearings. This service is available to all households, including public and private tenants and homeowners13.

sec.p: The ACT Government is also committed to making energy efficiency programs more accessible to underserved populations14. This includes providing targeted assistance and resources to low-income households and those facing barriers to accessing energy efficiency programs.
The ACT Government provides a range of assistance programs to help residents buy or rent homes:

list-item.p: Home Buyer Assistance: The ACT Government offers grants, stamp duty reductions, and other programs to assist with the purchase of a home. These programs aim to make homeownership more accessible and affordable for first-time buyers and other eligible residents15.
Rental Bond Assistance: Interest-free loans are available to help eligible tenants pay the bond for a private rental property. This helps to reduce the upfront costs associated with renting a home16.

Financial Support for Homeowners: The ACT Government provides financial support to help homeowners with the costs of owning and maintaining their homes. This includes assistance with lowering running costs, such as energy bills17.

sec.p: In addition to the policies, regulations, schemes, and programs mentioned above, the ACT Government has implemented other measures to promote energy efficiency in residential housing:

list-item.p: Energy Innovation Fund: This fund supports the development and deployment of innovative energy efficiency technologies in the ACT. This includes funding research and development projects, pilot programs, and community-based initiatives18.

Public Housing Programs: The ACT Government is committed to improving the energy efficiency of its public housing stock. This includes initiatives to upgrade insulation, install energy-efficient appliances, and provide energy advice to tenants19.

Types of Public and Community Housing: The ACT Government offers a variety of public and community housing options to meet the needs of different households. This includes single-family homes, apartments, and specialized housing for seniors and people with disabilities. Eligibility criteria and the application process vary depending on the type of housing20.
Option to Purchase: Eligible public housing tenants have the option to purchase their homes. This provides tenants with the opportunity to build equity and achieve homeownership21.

Community Education and Awareness: The ACT Government conducts various campaigns and initiatives to raise awareness about energy efficiency among residents. This includes providing information and resources on energy-saving tips, rebates, and programs22.

Home Energy Action Kit: This kit helps residents understand their energy and water usage and identify opportunities for improvement. The kit provides practical tips and resources to help households save energy and reduce their environmental impact23.

sec.p: Several research papers and reports have examined energy efficiency in residential housing in the ACT and beyond. These studies provide valuable insights into the effectiveness of different policies and programs, as well as the challenges and opportunities for further improvement.

One key area of research focuses on identifying effective Energy Efficiency Measures (EEMs) that can reduce energy consumption in homes. Studies have shown that measures such as insulation, heating and cooling upgrades, and efficient lighting can significantly reduce energy use and greenhouse gas emissions24.

Research has also explored the factors that influence the adoption of energy efficiency measures in households. Studies have identified barriers such as financial constraints, lack of awareness, and perceived complexity of upgrades25. Understanding these barriers and drivers is crucial for designing effective policies and programs that encourage energy efficiency upgrades.

Another important area of research examines the impact of energy efficiency on rental properties. Studies have shown that energy-efficient features in rental properties can lead to higher rental prices, suggesting a positive economic impact for property owners26.

Furthermore, research has highlighted the connection between energy efficiency and sustainable development goals27. Improving energy efficiency in residential housing contributes to broader sustainability goals, such as reducing greenhouse gas emissions, improving air quality, and promoting resource conservation.

Industry reports and white papers provide further insights into energy efficiency in residential housing in the ACT. One concern raised by industry reports is the potential impact of stricter energy efficiency standards on housing affordability28. While acknowledging the benefits of energy efficiency, some stakeholders argue that stricter standards could increase construction costs and make housing less affordable, particularly for first-time buyers and low-income households.

Industry stakeholders also emphasize the importance of market transformation strategies to encourage the adoption of energy-efficient technologies and practices29. Another key perspective from industry reports is the need for innovative financing mechanisms to support homeowners in making energy efficiency upgrades30.

Furthermore, industry reports highlight the importance of considering the long-term cost-effectiveness of energy efficiency measures31. This includes evaluating the payback periods for different upgrades and considering factors such as energy prices, maintenance costs, and the lifespan of energy-efficient technologies.
News articles and media reports provide updates on energy efficiency policies and initiatives in the ACT. Recent coverage has focused on several key developments:

list-item.p: New Energy Standards: The adoption of updated energy efficiency standards for new construction of single and multifamily homes has been a key topic in the news32.
Federal Funding: Media reports have highlighted the role of federal funding in supporting energy efficiency programs and initiatives in the ACT[^23].
Consumer Savings: News articles have reported on the significant energy savings that households are achieving through energy efficiency upgrades and programs[^24].

sec.p: Tasmania faces a unique challenge: despite having relatively low electricity prices, Tasmanians experience high energy bills due to several factors, including the cool climate, older housing stock with poor thermal efficiency, and a reliance on inefficient electric appliances for heating1. This paradox highlights the critical need for robust energy efficiency policies in the state.

To address this challenge, Tasmania has implemented several policies aimed at improving energy efficiency in residential housing. These policies are driven by the need to reduce energy consumption, lower household energy bills, and mitigate the impact of climate change.

One of the key policies is the Tasmanian Renewable Energy Target, which aims to increase the state’s renewable energy output by 200% based on 2022 figures by 20402. This target is supported by the Tasmanian Renewable Energy Action Plan, which outlines the government’s vision and actions for achieving this goal3.

Recognizing the need to improve the energy efficiency of existing homes, the state government has committed $15 million in the 2020/2021 Tasmanian Budget for public housing heating and energy efficiency initiatives4. This initiative aims to improve living conditions for public housing tenants while reducing energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions5.

Furthermore, the government acknowledges the disparity in energy efficiency ratings between homeowners and tenants, particularly those who are financially vulnerable6. Policy measures are being explored to address this disparity and ensure equitable access to energy-efficient housing for all Tasmanians.

The potential for energy efficiency policies to significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions is also recognized. Studies indicate that implementing these policies could reduce emissions by 40.3 million tonnes of CO2 equivalent (MtCO2-e) by 20507.

Tasmania has adopted regulations to ensure that new homes and renovations meet energy efficiency standards. These regulations are primarily based on the National Construction Code (NCC) and the Nationwide House Energy Rating Scheme (NatHERS).

It is important to note that the average energy efficiency rating of existing homes in Australia is only 1.7 stars, while in Tasmania, it is 4 stars8. This highlights the need for continuous improvement in the energy efficiency of the existing housing stock.

Since 2003, Tasmania has required mandatory energy efficiency measures for new housing9. In 2009, a “5 Star” requirement under NatHERS was introduced, and this was further increased to a “6-Star” standard in 201310. This 6-star standard plays a crucial role in driving the construction of energy-efficient homes in Tasmania11.

sec.p: NSW Government policies provide frameworks for energy efficiency in the residential housing sector, setting targets, defining standards, and guiding program development.

sec.title: NSW Energy Efficiency Action Plan
sec.p: The NSW Energy Efficiency Action Plan1 focuses on reducing household energy use and improving business energy productivity. The plan sets targets for annual energy savings of 16,000 gigawatt-hours by 2020 and aims to support 220,000 low-income households in reducing energy consumption.

sec.title: NSW Government Resource Efficiency Policy (GREP)
sec.p: The NSW Government Resource Efficiency Policy (GREP)2 addresses government operating costs and resource efficiency through measures in energy, water, waste, and air emissions. Key energy measures include:

list-item.p: Energy savings targets across government sites
Minimum National Australian Built Environment Rating System (NABERS) Energy ratings for offices and data centers
Standards for new electrical appliances and equipment
Standards for new buildings and fit-outs
Solar target implementation
Fuel efficiency standards for new light vehicles
6% GreenPower purchase requirement

sec.title: Australian Energy Efficiency Policy Handbook
sec.p: The Australian Energy Efficiency Policy Handbook3 outlines energy efficiency policies in Australia. It addresses energy retailer obligations, climate change policy alignment, and energy market policy coordination. The handbook discusses national residential energy efficiency disclosure schemes, rental property standards, and public housing upgrade programs.

sec.title: Regulations
sec.p: NSW Government regulations set standards for energy performance in residential housing. These regulations establish requirements for new and existing homes4.

sec.title: Building Sustainability Index (BASIX)
sec.p: The Building Sustainability Index (BASIX)5 sets minimum requirements for energy efficiency, water efficiency, and thermal comfort in new homes and renovations. BASIX supplements the National Construction Code (NCC) by providing a framework for sustainable building practices in NSW. The index evaluates climate zone, building design, and material selection factors to address environmental impact.

sec.title: Home Energy Efficiency Retrofits - Measurement of Energy Savings (HEER) Method Guide
sec.p: The HEER Method Guide6 provides methodology for measuring energy savings from residential building retrofits. It specifies requirements for calculating and verifying energy savings and defines roles for Accredited Certificate Providers (ACPs) and purchasers.

sec.title: Home Energy Ratings Disclosure Framework
sec.p: The Home Energy Ratings Disclosure Framework7 aims to standardize energy efficiency information disclosure for residential buildings. The framework coordinates with existing disclosure schemes and promotes consistency across jurisdictions. It focuses on providing clear energy performance information to inform consumer decisions.

sec.title: Schemes
sec.p: NSW Government schemes provide financial incentives and support for residential energy efficiency upgrades.

sec.title: Energy Savings Scheme (ESS)
sec.p: The Energy Savings Scheme (ESS)8 creates financial incentives for energy savings activities through a market for energy savings certificates (ESCs). Electricity retailers must acquire specified numbers of ESCs annually. The scheme continues until a comparable national scheme is introduced.
