sec.p: The Northern Territory faces unique challenges in ensuring energy efficiency due to its high household energy consumption, driven by extreme temperatures and the effects of climate change1. Rising temperatures, less predictable rainfall patterns, and the increasing intensity of cyclones further emphasize the need for a sustainable and resilient energy system2. This section outlines the key policies and regulations that govern energy efficiency in residential housing in the NT.

The Northern Territory Government has set a target of 50% renewable energy by 20303. This commitment is supported by various plans, strategies, and programs aimed at achieving a sustainable and affordable energy future for the Territory4. The government also participates in national energy reforms through the Energy National Cabinet Reform Committee, contributing to broader opportunities for the Territory and Australia, including the national hydrogen strategy5.

In alignment with the National Construction Code (NCC), new homes and modified homes requiring building permits in the NT must meet certain energy efficiency standards6. These standards are designed to:

list-item.p: Enhance the comfort of living spaces
Reduce energy bills over the lifetime of a home
Minimize greenhouse gas emissions7

sec.p: Specifically, houses must achieve a minimum 5-star energy rating, while apartments must achieve at least a 3.5-star rating8. A recent study has shown that despite meeting minimum energy efficiency design standards, predicted energy use for thermal comfort in new detached dwellings increased by 10.4% per dwelling and 5.6% nationally in 2022 compared to 20189. This trend can be attributed to several factors, including:

list-item.p: Increasing floor areas: As new homes are built with larger floor areas, the overall energy demand for heating and cooling increases, even with improved energy efficiency measures10.
Changes in household behavior: Increased use of appliances and electronic devices, along with changing lifestyle patterns, can contribute to higher energy consumption.

Limitations of minimum standards: The minimum energy efficiency standards may not be sufficient to offset the impact of these other factors, highlighting the need for continuous improvement in building codes and standards.

sec.p: The Northern Territory has adopted a variation to the NCC 2022 energy efficiency requirements for Class 1 and 10 buildings (houses and non-habitable buildings with a conditioned space)11. This variation, which came into effect on 1 October 2023, aims to improve understanding and use of the existing variation by including it in NCC 202212.
There are two options for complying with these requirements:

list-item.p: Achieving an energy rating of 5 stars or greater using house energy rating software (NatHERS).
Complying with NT Parts 13.1 through to 13.6 of the ABCB Housing Provisions13.

sec.p: For Class 2 buildings (apartments) and Class 4 parts of a building (dwellings within a non-residential building), Section J of BCA 2009 still applies14.

Energy hardship is a significant issue in the NT, particularly in remote communities and among households using prepayment meters15. Many households struggle to afford the energy they need, resulting in unmanageable power bills and frequent disconnections16. This situation can have serious consequences, including loss of food and medicine, and can exacerbate existing social and economic inequalities17. Addressing energy hardship requires a multi-faceted approach that includes:

list-item.p: Targeted energy concession schemes to improve affordability
Improving the energy performance of housing, particularly in remote communities
A planned and timely transition to renewable energy sources
Support for vulnerable households to manage their energy costs and avoid disconnections
Planning: Developing new energy systems that can effectively match energy demand and supply
Efficient energy use: Reducing total energy consumption through both behavioral changes and technological improvements
Energy storage: Integrating energy storage solutions to improve grid stability and resilience

sec.p: The Smarter Business Solutions program offers support to businesses, Aboriginal enterprises, and not-for-profit organizations in the NT to reduce their energy, water, waste, and material costs19. This program provides:

list-item.p: Advice on energy-efficient technologies and practices
On-site surveys to identify potential savings opportunities
Grants to support cost-saving initiatives, including renewable energy systems20

sec.p: Grants can cover up to 50% of the cost for efficiency improvements, up to a maximum of $20,00021. For renewable energy systems, grants cover up to 20% of the cost for off-grid systems and up to 10% for on-grid systems, with a maximum of $20,000 and $10,000 respectively22.

The Home and Business Battery Scheme provides grants to homeowners, businesses, and not-for-profit organizations in the NT to purchase and install batteries and inverters23. Eligible applicants can receive a grant of $400 per kilowatt-hour of usable battery system capacity, up to a maximum of $12,00024. This scheme aims to encourage the adoption of battery storage, which can help reduce reliance on the grid and lower energy costs25.

The Alice Springs Future Grid (ASFG) project focuses on facilitating the integration of renewable energy into the Alice Springs power system26. Led by the Intyalheme Centre for Future Energy, the ASFG project includes:

list-item.p: A Virtual Power Plant (VPP) trial
Community education initiatives
Research and development activities27

sec.p: Formerly known as the Household Energy Efficiency Scheme (HEES), Energy Ahead is a vital program designed to assist WA households in enhancing the energy efficiency of their homes1. Delivered in partnership with Energy Policy WA, state-owned electricity retailers Synergy and Horizon Power, and non-government organizations (NGOs)2, this program offers practical solutions and support to eligible households.

WA was once a leader in hardship energy efficiency programs, but the program was cut in 20123. The reintroduction of a program with similar goals through Energy Ahead highlights a renewed focus on energy efficiency and its importance in addressing cost-of-living pressures and climate change. The collaborative approach involving NGOs, Synergy, Horizon Power, and Energy Policy WA ensures that the program can effectively identify and support households most in need4.
Key features of Energy Ahead include:

list-item.p: One-on-one coaching: Eligible households receive personalized guidance from non-government organizations and retailers to identify and implement energy-saving measures. This coaching helps improve energy literacy and empowers residents to make informed decisions about their energy consumption5. Energy Ahead empowers households to understand their energy consumption and adopt energy-efficient behaviors and strategies6.

Appliance replacement: In certain cases, the program facilitates the replacement of inefficient appliances, such as refrigerators, with more energy-efficient models, further contributing to energy savings and reduced household expenses7.

Financial assistance: Energy Ahead aims to alleviate cost-of-living pressures for thousands of Western Australian households experiencing financial hardship by reducing energy bills through improved efficiency8.

sec.p: While not a scheme in itself, NatHERS plays a crucial role in promoting energy efficiency in Australian homes, including those in WA. NatHERS provides a star rating system (0 to 10 stars) that indicates the energy efficiency of a home, with higher ratings signifying better performance. This rating system helps homeowners and builders understand the energy performance of their homes and make informed decisions about design and construction to optimize energy efficiency.

Interestingly, the average Australian household has an energy efficiency rating as low as 1.8 out of 10 on the NatHERS scale9. This finding has significant implications for WA’s residential sector, suggesting a considerable potential for improvement in energy efficiency across the state.

WA has implemented various regulations to ensure the safety and efficiency of energy systems in residential buildings. These regulations cover aspects such as electrical work, gas installations, and appliance standards. Key regulations include:

list-item.p: Electricity (Licensing) Regulations 1991: These regulations govern the standards for electrical work in residential installations, licensing of electricians and contractors, and related procedural matters10. They also cover the WA Electrical Requirements, which specify supply service rules. These rules dictate the technical requirements for connecting a property to the electricity grid, including voltage levels, metering, and safety standards.

Gas Standards Regulations: Several regulations under the Gas Standards Act 1972 address gas supply, system safety, gasfitting, consumer installations, and infringement notices, ensuring the safe and efficient use of gas in homes11.

Minimum Energy Performance Standards (MEPS): While implemented at the national level, MEPS play a significant role in WA by setting minimum energy efficiency requirements for appliances and equipment. These standards ensure that new appliances sold in WA meet certain energy efficiency criteria, contributing to reduced energy consumption and lower household running costs12.

sec.p: The Australian Energy Efficiency Policy Handbook13 provides a national context for energy efficiency policies and offers recommendations for improvement. It highlights the need for:

list-item.p: Energy market reform: This includes implementing fair and efficient electricity tariff structures, improving the economic efficiency of electricity networks, and ensuring that Network Service Providers invest in demand-side measures to reduce expenditure.

Energy retailer obligations and energy efficiency funds: The handbook recommends establishing energy efficiency funds in every jurisdiction and strengthening energy retailer obligations through energy efficiency schemes.
Greenhouse gas reduction policies: It emphasizes the importance of aligning and integrating energy market and climate change policies to drive energy efficiency.

sec.p: The WA Climate Policy outlines the state government’s commitment to addressing climate change and transitioning to a low-carbon future14. This policy recognizes the importance of balancing economic growth with reductions in greenhouse gas emissions, particularly in the context of renewable energy policies15. It includes several actions aimed at improving energy efficiency in the residential sector, such as:

list-item.p: Energy efficiency in social housing: The government is actively working to improve the energy efficiency of social housing, reducing energy costs for low-income households and contributing to emissions reduction targets16.

Investment in climate resilience: The policy emphasizes investments in infrastructure to enhance climate resilience, including coastal adaptation and protection grants, which indirectly support energy efficiency by reducing the vulnerability of homes to extreme weather events17.

Electric vehicle (EV) charging infrastructure: The policy supports the development of EV charging infrastructure, encouraging the uptake of EVs and contributing to a cleaner transport sector, which indirectly reduces reliance on fossil fuels for energy generation18.

sec.p: Building upon the foundation of the WA Climate Policy, the WA Energy Transformation Strategy outlines a roadmap for the state’s energy future, focusing on a transition towards renewable energy sources and a more sustainable energy system19. This strategy includes initiatives that promote energy efficiency in residential housing, such as:

list-item.p: Schools Virtual Power Plant and Smart Energy for Social Housing scheme: These initiatives explore innovative approaches to energy management and efficiency in residential settings, potentially leading to wider adoption of similar technologies in the future20.

Pilot projects: The strategy emphasizes the importance of pilot projects to test and challenge the existing power system, identifying opportunities to enhance energy generation, access, sharing, and consumption, which could lead to improved energy efficiency in homes21.

Energy sector governance reforms: The strategy includes plans to investigate further governance changes to improve the efficiency of energy sector policy and decision-making, potentially leading to more effective energy efficiency regulations and programs22.

Technology upgrades: Drawing insights from the mining sector, where companies like Wesfarmers Coal Limited have achieved significant energy savings through technology upgrades23, the strategy recognizes the potential for similar improvements in the residential sector. This could involve promoting the adoption of energy-efficient appliances, smart home technologies, and renewable energy solutions in homes.

sec.p: While limited specific case studies were found focusing solely on WA residential energy efficiency policies, several examples highlight the implementation and impact of these measures:

list-item.p: Energy Ahead case study: A customer on a disability support pension with significant energy costs was referred to Energy Ahead. Through the program, they received assistance in understanding their energy consumption, implementing energy-saving strategies, and managing their energy bills, resulting in reduced financial hardship24. This case study demonstrates the program’s effectiveness in providing targeted support to vulnerable households and empowering them to improve their energy efficiency.

sec.p: Despite the progress made in promoting energy efficiency in WA’s residential housing sector, challenges remain. One notable challenge is the increasing energy use for thermal comfort in new dwellings, despite meeting minimum energy efficiency standards25. This highlights the limitations of current policies that focus primarily on energy efficiency on a square meter basis rather than overall household energy use.
To address this challenge, future policy directions should consider a more holistic approach to energy efficiency, targeting household energy use as a whole. This could involve:

list-item.p: Incentivizing smaller dwelling sizes: As floor area is a key determinant of energy use26, policies could encourage the construction of smaller, more energy-efficient homes.

Promoting energy-conscious design and behavior: Policies could encourage the adoption of passive design principles, which utilize natural elements like sunlight and ventilation to reduce reliance on artificial heating and cooling.

Strengthening energy efficiency requirements: Regularly reviewing and updating minimum energy performance standards for new buildings could ensure that they remain effective in driving down energy consumption.

sec.p: Western Australia is actively pursuing energy efficiency in the residential housing sector through a combination of schemes, regulations, and initiatives. Programs like Energy Ahead provide direct support to households, while regulations ensure the safety and efficiency of energy systems. The WA Climate Policy and Energy Transformation Strategy provide a framework for long-term improvements in energy efficiency, with a focus on reducing emissions and transitioning to a more sustainable energy future.

While these efforts are commendable, the analysis reveals a need for a more holistic approach to energy efficiency in residential housing. Future policies should move beyond simply setting minimum standards and consider the overall energy use of households. This could involve incentivizing smaller dwelling sizes, promoting energy-conscious design and behavior, and strengthening energy efficiency requirements. By addressing these challenges and adopting a more comprehensive approach, WA can further enhance energy efficiency in the residential sector, contributing to both cost savings for households and a more sustainable energy future for the state.
